content.definition: A chronic condition that develops after deep venous thrombosis (DVT), characterized by persistent symptoms and signs of venous hypertension including leg pain, swelling, skin changes, and ulceration. PTS results from venous valve damage, persistent obstruction, or both, leading to ambulatory venous hypertension.

epidemiology.timing: Usually develops within 2 years of DVT

mechanisms: Venous valve destruction from thrombus-induced inflammation
Persistent venous obstruction from incomplete recanalization
pathophysiology.consequence: Ambulatory venous hypertension - venous pressure fails to drop with calf muscle contraction

symptoms: Pain worse with standing, better with elevation

villalta_scale.symptoms: Pain, cramps, heaviness, pruritus, paresthesia (0-3 each)
villalta_scale.signs: Edema, skin induration, hyperpigmentation, new venous ectasia, redness, calf tenderness (0-3 each)

diagnosis.imaging: Duplex ultrasound to assess valve function and obstruction
diagnosis.timing: Assess ≥3 months after DVT (allow acute changes to resolve)

prevention.anticoagulation: Adequate intensity and duration - reduces PTS

compression_stockings.current_evidence: SOX trial showed no benefit for PTS prevention

prevention.thrombolysis: May reduce PTS in iliofemoral DVT (CaVenT, ATTRACT trials)

interventional.iliac_stenting: For iliofemoral obstruction with severe symptoms

learning_objectives: Use Villalta scale for diagnosis and grading
clinical_pearls: PTS develops in 20-50% of proximal DVT patients
Villalta score ≥5 = PTS diagnosis; ≥15 or ulcer = severe PTS
Iliofemoral DVT has HIGHEST PTS risk
SOX trial: compression stockings do NOT prevent PTS
Assess ≥3 months after DVT to diagnose PTS
Iliac stenting is effective for obstructive component
